title.narrative: Multi-Purpose cash assistance to conflict displaced households in Ghazni Province

description.narrative: RI proposes to support 800 households (5,600 individuals) with unconditional cash transfers for shelter in undeserved districts of Ghazni province, where conflict displacement is high, humanitarian needs are acute, and other humanitarian responders are not present. Ghazni has experienced displacement as a result of the upswing in conflict during the last 12 months. In the last six months, IDPs have numbered over 1,256 households, however, it is expected that many displaced have not been counted as access is limited to areas experiencing conflict. Areas of Ghazni remain under anti-government element (AGE) control – and little is understood of the nature of displacement. RI has access in areas beyond the control of other humanitarian responders and the Government of Afghanistan. RI currently has offices in Ghazni City, Muqur, Gelan and Qarabagh, and has the ability to scale up in the districts of Waghaz, Andar, Diyak. Malistan, Jaghori, Nawor, Khowaja Omary and Jaghato should a response be needed in these areas. DRC is the ERM responder in Ghazni, however they do not have access beyond the provincial capital. In the preparation of this proposal, RI has coordinated with UNHCR’s implementing partner in Ghazni, the Watan Social and Technical Services Association, who provide a small NFI/Food package for displaced households that have settled around Ghazni city. Their current response is geographically limited and inadequate. RI understands, from existing assessments and programming in the area that a fast and flexible response needs to be organized to support households to survive displacement. RI’s existing contacts with provincial and district governors, humanitarian responders (including OCHA’s own office), as well as a substantial ‘standing army’ of staff embedded in the communities allow the best chance of a response. This proposal has been reviewed by the shelter cluster to ensure alignment with shelter cluster technical guidelines and coverage of priority geographical areas. After discussion with the Cash Working Group RI will provide IDPs with unconditional cash transfers, to be used to support emergency shelter needs, and 'fill the gap' of other acute humanitarian needs. In the case that vulnerabilities mean the use of cash is inappropriate, RI will door-step deliver in-kind assistance. The cash distribution modality will be through bank transfer to Ghazni city, then Hawala on to the district centers, where RI staff will coordinate distribution.
